attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: cream
description: Cream is a dairy product that is composed of the higher-fat layer skimmed from the top of raw milk before homogenization. In the raw milk, over time, the lighter fat rises to the top. In many countries cream is sold in several grades depending on total fat content.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: cream cheese
description: Cream cheese is a soft, mild-tasting, white cheese that contains at least 33% milk fat with a moisture content of not more than 55%. [1] It is sold in brick form or in a small, tub-like container. Variety brands add such additional seasonings as garlic, dill, and olives. Cream cheese differs from other cheese in that it is not allowed time to mature and is meant to be consumed fresh. It is a primary ingredient in cheesecake and other desserts, and is often spread on bagels and eaten with lox (smoked salmon). On bagels, cream cheese is sometimes referred to by the Yiddish word schmear.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: cream of tartar
description: Cream of tartar is an acid produced during wine making. Other names potassium bitartrate, potassium hydrogen tartrate Appearance white crystalline powder Cream of tartar is the potassium acid salt of tartaric acid.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: cr�me de menthe
description: Crème de menthe is a sweet, mint-flavoured liqueur. Its flavour is primarily derived from Corsican mint. It is available commercially in a colourless (called "white") and a green form, which obtains its colour from the mint leaves or from the addition of colouring, if extract and not the leaves are used to make the liqueur. Both varieties have similar flavours and are interchangeable in recipes, except where the colour is important.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: cr�me fra�che
description: Crème fraiche is a soured cream containing about 28% butterfat and with a pH of around 4.5. It is soured with bacterial culture, but is thicker, and less sour than sour cream. Crème fraiche is produced by a process similar to that of sour cream, with the exception that no ingredients are added. Each processing step requires attention to maintain high viscosity. It can be made at home by adding a small amount of cultured buttermilk or sour cream to heavy cream, and allowing it to stand for several hours at room temperature until the bacterial cultures act on the cream.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: cucumber
description: The cucumber, also known as the cuke, is a green vegetable related to the squash and melon. Cucumbers are popular in salads and as pickles.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: culantro
description: Culantro (also known as Bhandhanya, Chandon benit, Culantro, Culantro Coyote, Fitweed, Long coriander, Mexican coriander, Wild coriander, Recao, Spiritweed, Ngò gai, Sawtooth, and Saw-leaf herb), is the leaves of the herb Eryngium foetidum. It is native to Mexico and South America, but is cultivated worldwide. In the United States, where it is not well-known, the name culantro sometimes causes confusion with Coriandrum sativum, the leaves of which are known as cilantro.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: cumin
description: Cumin (Cuminum cyminum) comes from Western Asia, where it has been cultivated since Biblical times. People cook with the fruits of the plant, which are usually referred to as the seeds.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: curd
description: Curds are a dairy product obtained by curdling (coagulating) milk with rennet or an edible acidic substance such as lemon juice or vinegar and then draining off the liquid portion (called whey). Milk that has been left to sour (raw milk alone or pasteurized milk with added lactic acid bacteria or yeast) will also naturally produce curds, and sour milk cheese is produced this way.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: currant
description: The currant is a small fruit, commonly available dried or in jelly. There are three types of currants:
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: curry leaf
description: Curry Leaf is used in most Indian delicacies, it adds flavor and spicy pleasant smell to the dish. Typically, is fried during tadka or bhagaar - the process of frying spices before adding vegetables for making curry.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: curry powder
description: Curry powder is a blend of spices used in South and South East Asian cuisine. Different curries include many different combinations of spices, and are typically sold in powder or paste form. Common spices included in curry blends include tumeric, black or white pepper, red pepper, and coriander.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: daikon
description: Daikon (大根) is a mild-flavored Japanese giant white radish usually called daikon radish in United States supermarkets. Although there are many varieties of daikon, the most common is carrot shaped, approximately 8-14 inches long and 2-4 inches in diameter.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: dal
description: Dal (also spelt Dahl) is an Indian term that means split, often hulled (skin removed) dried legumes, and can cover many different types of legume.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: dandelion
description: The greens of the dandelion plant are sometimes used raw in salads, sautéed or steamed. They taste like chicory and endive, with an intense heartiness overlying a bitter tinge.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: dashi
description: Dashi is a broth used to make miso soup.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: date
description: Dates are the fruit of the date palm. They are widely eaten as dried fruit and in cooking throughout the Middle East and North Africa.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: demerara sugar
description: Demerara is a large-grained, yellowish brown sugar with slightly sticky crystals and a relatively low molasses content - hence its paler color and milder flavor. Said to be a more natural product (fewer or no chemicals used in its manufacture) than brown sugar, it's a popular product for tea and coffee in England, Australia and Canada, but not very well known in the U.S. It makes an excellent table sugar and can be used for decorating cookies or as the caramelizing sugar on creme brulee.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: demi-glace
description: Demi'glace is prepared by the slow reduction of a mixture of sauce espagnole and brown stock.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: dijon mustard
description: Dijon mustard is a prepared mustard made from husked black or brown mustard seeds, where black seeds are usually considered the strongest and most flavorful. Originally Dijon mustard was blended with verjuice, but today's Dijon mustard is usually blended with wine or vinegar. Additionally salt and other spices are added to lend it a special spicy flavor. True Dijon mustard is actually pale yellow and not brown. It comes in many additional flavored varieties but also ranges from mild in flavor to the very hot.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: dill
description: Dill is a short-lived, European, annual herb. Both the fern-like leaves and the seed are used.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: dough
description: Dough (Pâte in French, Pasta in Italian) is a paste made out of the flour of any cereal (grain) or leguminous food, moistened and kneaded but not baked. This step is a precursor to its use in cooking in numerous ways such as making bread, pasta, noodles, pastry, cookies and muffins among other uses. Dough differs from batter in having a lower water content.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: duck
description: Ducks have many domestic uses, being farmed for their meat, eggs, and feathers and down. In many areas, ducks of various species are hunted for sport and food.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: duck stock
description: Duck Frame Stock
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: durian
description: Durian (Durio) is a green, spiny fruit from Southeast Asia. This "King of Fruits" has a complex, rich flavor and an intense odor which many find offensive. The fruit's stench has caused it to be banned from public places in some countries and has caused evacuations. Durians can sometimes be found in normal supermarkets in Western countries, frozen and thickly wrapped in plastic.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: edible cactus
description: Edible cactus is also known as nopales (no-PAH-les), nopalitos, cactus paddles, or cactus pads. This vegetable is popular in Mexico and other Central American countries, parts of Europe, the Middle East, India, North Africa and Australia. Its popularity is increasing in the United States, where it can be found at Mexican grocery stores, specialty produce markets and farmer’s markets.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: eel
description: Eels are an order of fish, which consists of four suborders, 19 families, 110 genera and approximately 600 species.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: eel sauce
description: Eel sauce (kabayaki sauce) is commonly used in the preparation of broiled fresh water eel (unagi) and salt water eel (anago.) The thick, sweet, hickory flavored sauce is heated and drizzled on sushi prepared with eel. Eel sauce is also delicious with other sushi and non-sushi creations alike. Eel sauce includes soy sauce, syrup, fertilized eel eggs, and mirin. The texture and flavor is a perfect match for toasted unagi. It is best to heat eel sauce in a metal or glass container placed in 3/4 inch boiling water on the stove.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: egg
description: Bird and fish eggs are common food sources. For fish eggs, see caviar. Reptile eggs, particularly turtle eggs, are sometimes eaten as well. Chicken eggs are standard. Duck, goose, quail, and ostrich eggs (the largest edible bird eggs in the world) are occasionally used as gourmet ingredients.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: egg white
description: Egg white is the common name for the clear liquid (also called albumen or glair/glaire) contained within an egg. It is the cytoplasm of the egg, which until fertilization is a single cell. It consists mainly of about 10% proteins dissolved in water. Its primary purpose is to protect the egg yolk and also to provide additional nutrition for the growth of the embryo, as it is rich in proteins and is of high nutritional value. Unlike the egg yolk, it contains little fat.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: egg yolk
description: An egg yolk is the part of an egg which serves as the food source for the developing embryo inside. Prior to fertilization the yolk together with the germinal disc is a single cell. Mammalian embryos live off their yolk until they implant on the wall of the uterus. The egg yolk is suspended in the egg white (known more formally as albumen or ovalbumin) by one or two spiral bands of tissue called the chalazae.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: eggplant
description: Eggplant (also known as aubergine) is a shiny bulbous vegetable in the nightshade family that comes in green, white, or, more commonly, purple. The eggplant itself is actually a berry, and its edible watertight skin and disc-like seeds show clearly its similarity to peppers and tomatoes. Unlike its cousins, however, the eggplant has a firm, dense flesh that is too bitter to eat raw. Eggplants range in size from large purple gourds bigger than a person's hand to tiny marble-sized green Asian eggplants. The smaller varieties are said to be less bitter and to need less preparation. Many people find eggplant to be an acquired taste. Its versatility leads to eggplant dishes in many different cuisines, from Japan to India to Italy.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: emmental cheese
description: Emmental, or Emmentaler, is the cheese widely known as Swiss cheese in North America, Australia, and New Zealand. It is a yellow, medium-hard cheese with a mildly tangy flavour from lactic acid fermentation. It is characterised by large holes left by gas bubbles produced during fermentation of the cheese.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: endive
description: Endive (Cichorium endiva) is a leafy salad vegetable. It is often confused with chicory.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: fava bean
description: Fava beans, also faba beans, ful, horse beans, are strong flavoured beans with tough hulls. Large fava beans are often called broad beans in English-speaking countries.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: feijoa
description: The Feijoa or pineapple guava is an egg-shaped fruit with a thin lime-green skin. The flesh inside is cream-colored and encases a jelly-like center. The texture is gritty, close to that of a pear. The flesh tastes like a combination of several other fruits, usually described as pineapple, guava, and strawberry. Some people report a taste similar to that of a quince or lemon. Feijoa is native to South America, but is now commercially grown in New Zealand and California.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: fennel
description: Fennel is both a vegetable and a spice.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: fenugreek
description: Fenugreek, or Trigonella foenum-graecum, is native to India and southern Europe. People cook with the hard, yellow-brown seeds that come from the plant's pods. Fenugreek contains only minute quantities of an essential oil. Indian cooking often employs fresh fenugreek leaves, which are eaten sautéed, or dried and used as a flavoring.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: feta cheese
description: Feta cheese is a soft white crumbly cheese often used on salads. It is traditionally made from goat's milk or sheep's milk, although it is often made from cow's milk in some countries.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: fiddlehead
description: Fiddleheads, also known as fiddle greens, are the coiled growing tips of ostrich ferns. They are more often available in spring.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: fig
description: The fig is a fruit. Though exquisite when fresh and ripe, it spoils far too quickly to make fresh fruit practical. Figs are usually available in dried form. There are two main types of fig, the small dark ones (mission figs) and the large pale ones (all others: calimyrna, kadota, brown turkey, etc.). Most dried figs are mission figs, but the other types generally taste a little better.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: fines herbes
description: Fines herbes is a mixture of herbs used in French cuisine. It normally contains parsley, chives, tarragon and chervil.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: fish
description: Fish are odorless, nutritious, and tasty.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: fish sauce
description: Fish Sauce, also nước mắm (Vietnam), nam pla (น้ำปลา - Thailand), jeotgal (Korea), is a sauce made by fermenting various types of fish (usually anchovies) and pressing to extract the liquid.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: five spice powder
description: Chinese five spice powder (五香粉 or five spices powder or five-spice powder) is a convenient seasoning for Cantonese cuisine. It incorporates the five basic flavours of Chinese cooking - sweet, sour, bitter, pungent, and salty. One common recipe includes China Tung Hing cinnamon, powdered cassia buds, powdered star anise and anise seed, ginger root, and ground cloves. Another recipe for the powder consists of cinnamon, black pepper, cloves, fennel seed, and star anise. It is used in most Cantonese roasted ducks, as well as beef stew.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: fleischbutter
description: Fleischbutter (meat butter) is a combination of ground meat, butter, and spices, used as a spread. Fleischbutter is popular in some German regions (south-west), and either unknown or considered inedible in others (north/east). The most common form of fleischbutter is made with ground pork; variants use beef, lamb, kidney, tripe, and other muscle and organ meats. Spices also vary considerably.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: florence fennel
description: Florence fennel is variety of fennel that has been bred to grow a bulbous stem, which can be used as a vegetable. It has a crunchy texture and a flavour between celery and aniseed.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: flour
description: An ingredient used in many foods, flour is a fine powder made from cereal grain or other starchy food sources. It is most commonly made from wheat, but also corn, rye, barley and rice, amongst many other grasses and even non-grain plants.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: flour tortilla
description: Tortillas are a type of flatbread popular in Mexico and Central America commonly made from wheat flour or masa. This recipe is for the wheat flour variety.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: foie gras
description: Foie gras (pronounced /fwɑːˈgrɑː/ in English; French for "fat liver") is "the liver of a duck or a goose that has been specially fattened by gavage (as defined by French law). Pâté de foie gras is the most famous dish prepared from it.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: fond blanc de boeuf
description:
Fonds blanc de boeuf White Beef Stock
Fonds brun de boeuf Brown Beef Stock
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: fond blanc de veau
description:
Fonds blanc de veau White veal stock
Fonds brun de veau Brown veal stock
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: frisee
description: Frisee is a curly-leafed salad vegetable (sometimes referred to as 'baby curly endive'). It is a close relative to Chicory or Endive (which, to add confusion are actually the same thing only with different names on different continents). The outside leaves of the frisee are very coarse and bitter, so they are generally discarded. Try to choose a head with many small baby leaves instead, as they are much milder.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: frog
description: Frog legs taste like a cross between chicken wings and shark. They would go well baked with teriyaki sauce. They can be deep-fat fried like fish.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: fructose
description: Fructose is the chemical name for the kind of sugar found in most fruits. Sugar found in corn and human blood is called glucose. Normal table sugar, produced from sugar cane or sugar beets, is called sucrose.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: fungus
description: There are many edible fungi including:
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: galangal
description: Galangal is a member of the ginger family, but it has a distinctly different flavour to ginger. Other names include galanga, galangale, laos, and blue ginger.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: game
description: Game are wild animals and birds. Farm-raised game are originally wild species of animals and birds that have been raised for sale. Large native game animals living in North America include antelope, buffalo, bear, caribou, deer, elk, moose, reindeer, and wild boar. Elsewhere in the world, even rarer varieties eaten by humans are camel, elephant, kangaroo, wild goats, wild sheep, zebra, and other species.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: garam masala
description: Garam masala, literally "hot spice" in Hindi, is a term for a mixture of spices used in Indian cooking. Many commercial brands are available, but keen cooks can grind and blend their own. This ensures freshness and means you have control over the quality and quantities of the individual spices. There is no one 'official' recipe and many Indian families have their own variety. Make your choice from the list of spices below, and grind them together with a pestle and mortar, spice mill (or pepper mill), or electric coffee grinder. Make small quantities, and store in an airtight container for no more than six months.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: garlic
description: Garlic is a pungently odoriferous member of the allium family (like onions and leeks). Garlic is generally used as a spice or a seasoning rather than as a vegetable due to its extremely strong flavour.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: garlic powder
description: Garlic powder is dehydrated garlic cloves that have been ground to a white-yellow powder. It provides some of the flavour, but not the texture, of fresh garlic, lasts for a long period of time and disperses well in liquid, hence the usage in marinades. High quality brands consist of pure garlic, while low quality brands may add artificial colour and flavour enhancers.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: garlic salt
description: Garlic salt is a spice commonly found in the U.S.. It is a mixture of garlic and salt as the name suggests.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: gelatine
description: Gelatine (also gelatin) is a clear, flavourless substance used as a stabiliser or thickener in many foods. It is derived from the breakdown of collagen from the skin, bones and connective tissues of animals after simmering for an extended period.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: gem squash
description: Gem squash is a small, round summer squash with a dark green skin and yellow flesh. The skin can be quite thick or thin enough to eat, depending on when the squash was harvested.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: ghee
description: Ghee, or clarified butter, is butterfat that has been separated from the water, proteins, and salt in butter. Ghee is used heavily in Indian cuisine. It is considered an extremely pure food in South Asia, and may be used to anoint representations of the deities, both in home worship, performed by laity, and in Temple worship, performed by Brahmin priests.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: giblets
description: Giblets are the edible offal of a fowl, typically including the heart, gizzard, liver and other visceral organs.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: ginger
description: Ginger is used extensively as a cooking ingredient or spice in Asian cuisine and others. It is part of mainstream western food in ginger beer and desserts such as gingerbread and ginger snaps (a type of cookie). Though generally called "root", it is actually the rhizome of the plant Zingiber officinalis.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: gluten
description: Gluten is a protein found as a major component of wheat, rye and barley. Gluten can be separated from the starch and is useful to make dough more elastic and bread made with additional gluten is more firm, remains fresh and in its form.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: gluten free, wheat free flour
description: Various gluten free and wheat free flours are available. For people with celiac disease and no wheat allergy, gluten free flour is probably the best option as it is the most similar to normal flour. Gluten free flour is available in most supermarkets and can be obtained on prescription in some places if you have a diagnosis of celiac disease. Wheat free flours are a little more difficult to get hold of and can be harder to cook with but there are many different types available. Be aware that some wheat free flours still contain gluten, however wheat free and gluten free flours are available. Some of the most common wheat free flours are: potato flour, rice flour and soya flour.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: goat
description: Goat is an animal from Southwestern Asia and Eastern Europe. The Goat is of the Bovidae and is closely related to the sheep. The Goat is also a food, used for milk and meat. When the Goat Meat comes from an adult, it's called Mutton. When it's a young animal, it's capperato or kid. Usually in particularly Bangladesh, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Pakistan and India, "mutton" is referred to Goat and Sheep.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: gochugaru
description: Gochugaru (고추가루, also transliterated as go choo ga roo) is red chili pepper, dried and ground into a coarse powder. In preparing Korean dishes, just about any ground chili pepper may be used as a substitution, but be aware that several varieties of chili powder (such as cayenne pepper) can be quite a bit hotter or milder than gochugaru, and so it is advisable to add in small amounts until the desired level of spiciness is reached.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: golden syrup
description: Golden syrup is a moderately thick cane syrup.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: goose
description: The goose (plural: geese) is a bird with the size of a turkey and the shape of a duck. Geese are often served as part of holiday meals.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: gooseberry
description: The gooseberry is a bittersweet little berry that the English have a passion for. Gooseberry wines, pies and puddings were very popular in colonial days. Today most such recipes have all but disappeared from cookbooks.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: gorgonzola cheese
description: Gorgonzola cheese is an Italian cheese invented in the early Middle Ages. It is made from unskimmed cow's milk and has a 'bite' from its marbled greenish-blue veining of mold introduced to the cheese in the eleventh century.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: graham cracker
description: Graham crackers were originally conceived as a "health food" made from whole wheat (specifically, Graham flour), but have since entered the cuisine of the USA as a basic biscuit often made from highly refined flour with added sugar or honey.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: graham flour
description: Graham flour is a type of flour made from wheat in accordance with the designs of American religious minister Sylvester Graham. It is a special variation of whole wheat flour, made by mixing finely milled white flour with coarsely milled bran and wheatgerm, in the proportions that they would be found in a whole wheat berry.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: granulated sugar
description: Granulated sugar is pure sucrose, chemically the same as superfine (also known as caster or castor) sugar. The crystals are not as fine though. Typically one type may be substituted for the other.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: grape
description: The grape is a popular small fruit. Dried grapes are called raisins. Grapes are commonly used to make jam, jelly, and wine.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: grape seed oil
description: Grape seed oil is a vegetable oil pressed from the seeds of Vitis vinifera grapes, an abundant byproduct of wine making. Grape seed oil is used for: salad dressings, marinades, deep frying, flavored oils, baking, massage oil, sunburn repair lotion, hair products, body hygiene creams, lip balm and hand creams.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: grapefruit
description: The grapefruit is a large citrus fruit that is moderately sour and slightly bitter. It is well-known for causing dangerous interactions with drugs, so be sure to investigate this if you are taking any medication. Pink or red grapefruits tend to be sweeter and have more vitamins than the "white" (yellow) grapefruits.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: green bean
description: The green bean, also known as the snap bean or string bean, is a type of bean that is eaten with the pod. Green beans are normally eaten fresh or nearly fresh, not dried.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: green olive
description: The green olive is a pickled olive, normally stuffed with a pimento but sometimes containing the pit, an anchovy, an almond, or nothing at all. Green olives are usually sold in glass jars.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: green onion
description: Green onions (also known as scallions and spring onions) are usually one of various members of the onion family that do not form bulbs. Occasionally, whole immature shallots are used in the same way. Green onions tend to be milder tasting than other onions and are typically used raw in salads.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: green pepper
description: Green Pepper is an ambiguous term. Certainly, it involves a green-colored chili pepper. Beyond that though...
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: gremolata
description: Gremolata is a chopped herb condiment typically made of lemon zest, garlic and parsley. It is a traditional accompaniment to the Milanese braised veal shank dish Ossobuco.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: gruy�re cheese
description: Gruyère IPA: [ɡʁy.jɛʁ] (Groo-Yair) is a hard yellow cheese made from cow's milk, named after the town of Gruyères in Switzerland, and made in the cantons of Fribourg, Vaud, Neuchâtel, Jura, and Berne. Before 2001, when Gruyère gained Appellation d'Origine Contrôlée status as a Swiss cheese, some controversy occurred as to whether French cheeses of a similar nature could also be labelled Gruyère. (French Gruyère-style cheeses include Comté and Beaufort.) French Gruyère-style cheeses must have holes according to French agricultural law, whereas Swiss Gruyère is a solid cheese with no holes.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: guar gum
description: Guar Gum is derived from seeds of guar plant native to India. Primarily used in gluten free recipes using hypoallergenic grain flours.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: guava
description: The guava, also known as the bangkok apple or guayaba, is an oval-shaped fruit. It varies in size from a small egg to a medium apple. The thin skin may be yellow, red, purple or nearly black and the flesh ranges from a pale yellow to a bright red. Guava is sweet with a slight tart aftertaste. Its texture is firm; similar to an apple. Guava is native to South America, but is now commonly grown in California, Florida, Hawaii and most parts of Africa and tropical Asia.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: gula jawa
description: Gula Jawa (Coconut Sugar) is made from the Borassus (Palmyra palm) and is used in Javanese cuisine. One can substitute either brown sugar (preferred substitution) or white sugar for Gula Jawa.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: habanero
description: A habanero (not habañero) is an unbelievably hot chili pepper, often rated between 200,000 to 300,000 Scoville heat units. Although not eaten by most, there is a niche for habaneros from some of those who like hot food. Merely touching them can cause a strong burning sensation. Brushing contaminated hands on any other body part, particularly the face and genitals, can lead to excruciating pain. Particular caution should be made when dropping habaneros in to hot oil, as the steam that rises will cause irritation if it hits the eyes or other membranes.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: hagfish
description: Hagfish are chewy, with a softer spinal cord that runs through their back, and have a mild taste, with an unpleasant aftertaste. Though unpalatable to foreigners, they are popular in Korea, where they are usually eaten by men as an aphrodisiac. For that purpose they are considered by Korean men to be interchangeable with eels, an unrelated animal with a similarly phallic shape but remarkably different taste and texture.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: hake
description: Hake is a whitefish with a moist, flaky texture and a subtle flavour, like a milder version of cod. It is also sometimes known as ling or whiting, although in the UK, "whiting" is used to mean a different, less tasty fish.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: half and half
description: In this cookbook, half and half refers to a mixture of 50% milk and 50% cream. This is available as a pre-mixed product in the USA, so many American recipes specify it as an ingredient.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: ham
description: The word ham means pork which comes from the hind leg of a hog. Ham made from the front leg of a hog will be labeled "pork shoulder picnic." "Turkey" ham must be made from the thigh meat of turkey.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: hard boiled eggs
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: haw
description: Hawberries are berries known to grow on Manitoulin Island thanks to its distinctive alkaline soil. During the pioneer days, white settlers ate these berries during the winter as the only remaining food supply. People who saw these settlers collecting the berries started to call them "haweaters". People born on the island are now called "haweaters".
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: hazelnut
description: Hazelnuts are the nut of the common hazel. They are often used in desserts in combination with chocolate.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: heart of palm
description: Heart of palm, also called palm heart, palmito, or swamp cabbage, is a vegetable harvested from the inner core and growing bud of certain palm trees (notably the coconut (Cocos nucifera), Palmito Juçara (Euterpe edulis), Açaí palm (Euterpe oleracea), sabal (Sabal spp.) and pejibaye (Bactris gasipaes) palms). It is costly because harvesting kills the tree. It is eaten raw, usually in salads, and has a mild, slightly sweet nutty flavor and a pleasant texture. In appearance it is off-white and usually sold as round stalks about an inch in diameter and 4-5 inches long, in jars or cans with salt water.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: herbes de provence
description: Herbes de Provence or Provençal herbs is a mixture of the herbs traditionally used in the cooking of Provence, France. The mixture was created in the 1970s to simplify the use of these herbs; traditional cooks did not have such a mixture, instead using the individual herbs in amounts suitable to their own tastes. Although a few commercial mixtures do not have it, many cooks consider that Herbes de Provence without lavender is not really Herbes de Provence.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: herring
description: A herring is a type of small oily fish found in the temperate, shallow waters of the North Atlantic. A smaller variant lives in the Baltic Sea.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: hoisin sauce
description: Hoisin or Hoi Sin sauce is a sweet bean sauce made from fermented soy beans. It can be found in most Asian supermarkets. It is one of the most widely known of the sauces, liked for its balance of sweetness, saltiness, garlic and five-spice powder. It is a staple of many Asian cuisines such as Chinese, Vietnamese, and Taiwanese.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: hominy
description: Hominy, also known as nixtamal, is corn treated with lye. The corn is soaked in water with lye to remove the hard outer hulls. This process makes the corn more palatable, easier to digest, and easier to process. The process also converts some of the niacin in the maize into a form more absorbable by the body.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: honey
description: Honey is a sweet and viscous liquid produced by bees from the nectar of flowers . The flavor and color of the honey is largely determined by the type of flowers from which the nectar is gathered. Common flavours of honey include orange blossom honey, tupelo honey, clover honey, blackberry, and blueberry honey. In Australia, Tasmanian leatherwood honey is considered a delicacy for its unique flavour. Manuka honey from New Zealand is said by some to have more healing properties than other honeys, therefore sells at a premium price.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: hop shoot
description: The tender young shoots of the hop, in season for a very short period in spring, can be lightly boiled and used as a garnish, starter, or accompanying vegetable. They have a flavour similar to asparagus.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: horn salt
description: Horn salt (also hartshorn) is used in some traditional Northern European baked goods as a leavening agent.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: horned melon
description: The horned melon, also known as the kiwano melon and African horned melon, is an oval-shaped fruit with horns on its peel. It has a bright orange and yellow skin with a pale yellow-green pulp inside. The flavor of the pulp is sweet and a bit tart with a flavor mix of bananas, lime and cucumber. Horned melon is native to southern and central Africa. Most imported melons are now from New Zealand. California has began growing this melon, so a domestic product is available part of the year.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: horseradish
description: Horseradish is a member of the mustard family and is native to Eastern Europe, although it may have originated in Asia: Germany, or the Mediterranean area. The ancient Greeks used it, so did the Hebrews — it is one of the 5 bitter herbs of the Jewish Passover. The strong flavor of this root has an underlying sweetness and seems more like garlic than a spice.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: hot dog
description: A hot dog (also known as a frankfurter) is a variant on a sandwich, or the sausage inside, usually made of beef. In consists of a bun and a frankfurter sausage, and usually has a variety of toppings, including ketchup, mustard, relish, onions, and pickles. Cheese is also a popular topping for Hot Dogs. Hot Dogs range in size, and can be up to a foot long.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: huacatay
description: Huacatay, pronounced wah-kah-tye, also Peruvian black mint, is a herb used in Peruvian cuisine. The fresh leaves are ground into a paste, which is then used to add flavour to recipes.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: hummus
description: Hummus, also hoummus, hommus, hommous, is a blend of sesame seed paste and either chickpea paste or fava bean paste. This cookbook has three different recipes for Hummus:
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: hyssop
description: Hyssop is a semi evergreen shrub or "sub-shrub" with aromatic leaves and spikes of blue, two-lipped, late-summer flowers.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: isomalt
description: Isomalt is produced by turning normal sugar into a chemical that the human body treats as a dietary fiber. Because of this, it does not produce an insulin response and is safe for diabetics. Isomalt is also undigestable by oral bacteria, reducing the damage they can cause to teeth and gums (and through remineralisation, it even helps to build dental enamel, thus reducing the formation of plaque). Isomalt is a registered trademark of Palatinit.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: jackfruit
description: The jackfruit is a very large fruit from trees native to south-western India and Sri Lanka. Jackfruit can be up to 90cm long, 50cm in diameter, and weight up to 36kg. The taste is similar to that of pineapple, but milder and less juicy. It is popular throughout South Asia and South-east Asia.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: jaggery
description: Jaggery is an unrefined crude brown sugar. It can be made from the sap of the East Indian jaggery palm, or from sugar cane. When made from the jaggery palm, it is often called gur to differentiate it from the sugar cane product. It is usually sold in solid blocks of a brownish-yellow color, and is used extensively in Indian dishes and sweets as well as traditional medicine. It has a much stronger flavor than refined cane sugar, but raw cane sugar may be substituted in many recipes if jaggery is unavailable.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: jalape�o
description: A jalapeño is a very hot variety of chili pepper that can be used in a variety of dishes, mostly from the U.S. Southwest. It is also be made into such condiments as jalapeño jelly.[1][2]
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: jamaican jerk spice
description: Jamaican jerk spice is a pungent, hot mixture of spices used to flavor meats before grilling or roasting.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: jicama
description: Jicama (pronounced hickama) is a legume, a relative of the bean family. It is a popular dietary staple in Latin America and widely grown in Mexico and Central America. There are many names for Jicama including: the Mexican potato, Mexican yam bean, ahipa, saa got, Chinese turnip, lo bok, and the Chinese potato.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: juice
description: Juice is the name given to the liquid part of fruits, and also of vegetables and meats. Juice is extracted from fruit in the making of beverages, jellies, syrups, cordials, confectionery, desserts, sauces, reductions, etc. and also for many flavouring purposes.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: juniper berry
description: Juniper Berry - actually the cones of certain juniper trees, especially Junperus communis. It is used as a spice in European cuisines, and is the flavour in gin.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: kaffir lime leaf
description: Kaffir lime leaves are the leaves of a lime tree native to Indonesia. Kaffir lime leaves are used in several South-East Asian cuisines, adding a sour, citrus-like flavour to foods cooked with them.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: kale
description: Kale is a very bitter open-headed member of the cabbage family. It can be cooked in combination with Collard greens or with other milder ingredients to soften its harsh flavour. It can also be substituted for spinach in most dishes.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: kamut
description: Kamut
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: kangkung
description: Kangkung, also kangkong, ong choy, water spinach, river spinach, swamp cabbage is a leafy green vegetable grown throughout tropical and subtropical countries but most commonly throughout South-East Asia.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: kelp
description: Kelp, known as kombu or konbu in Japanese cuisine, is a type of seaweed.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: kidney
description: Kidneys are organs that extract waste from blood to create urine. They are most commonly used in British pie recipes. Template:Cookbook-stub
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: kidney bean
description: Kidney beans are flavoursome beans used widely in cooking in many countries. They are generally found as dried beans, and the term "kidney beans" usually refers to red kidney beans.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: kielbasa
description: Kiełbasa is a Polish word for traditional Polish Sausage. The word has become a commonly used North American term for Eastern European styles of sausage, including Ukrainian sausage, which is called kovbasa or kubasa.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: kiwifruit
description: The kiwifruit (or kiwi[1]) is a fruit. It is the size of a large hens egg, and a is grown only in temperate climates. Kiwifruit flesh is said to taste and feel vaguely like strawberries, but with a strong green taste. When canned, kiwifruit become mushy and lose their color.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: kohlrabi
description: Kohlrabi (also kohl-rabi) is a low and stout biennial. It originated in Germany around 4,000 years ago and is a member of the cabbage family (Gongylodes group). It is a cabbage that was selected for its swollen stems -- in German 'kohl' is cabbage and 'rabi' is turnip and it is so called because it has cabbage-like leaves and a turnip-like bulb above ground.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: konfyt
description: Konfyt - refers to Malay-style fruit preserves. The fruit is soaked in slaked lime water overnight to tenderise the inside of the fruit and retain the firmness of the skin. After gentle steaming, the fruit is boiled in a syrup of water, sugar and lemon juice; then transferred to a sterilized glass jar which is topped up with the remaining syrup. Green fig preserve, with a hint of cinnamon, is outstanding and a perfect accompaniment to cheeses.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: kumquat
description: The kumquat is a type of citrus fruit.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: lamb
description: Lamb is meat from sheep less than 1 year old. Most are brought to market at about 6 to 8 months old.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: lard
description: Lard is fat (the thick oil, not the fat tissue) from a pig. Unlike shortening, which can be used as a lard substitute, lard is free of trans-fatty acids. Lard is also lower in saturated fat than butter, making lard one of the best of the well-known solid fats.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: lardon
description: Lardons are bits of lard that can be injected into a tough piece of meat prior to cooking. The injection of lardons is called larding.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: leek
description: The leek is a vegetable related to onions, chives, and garlic. Also in this species are two very different vegetables: The elephant garlic (A. ampeloprasum var. ampeloprasum) grown for its bulbs, and kurrat which is grown for its leaves in Egypt and elsewhere in the Middle East.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: legumes
description: The 'Bean' family includes many and varied varieties of legume. (pea, soybean, lentil, etc.) The vanilla bean is unrelated.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: lemon
description: Lemons are citrus fruit from the tree Citrus limon. They are cultivated primarily for their juice, though the pulp and rind are also used, primarily in cooking or mixology. Lemon juice is about 5% citric acid, which gives lemons a sour taste.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: lemon juice
description: Lemon juice is squeezed from a lemon. Before cutting the lemon, roll it back and forth between the hands, to break up the membranes containing the juice. Then cut the lemon, and squeeze each half into a clean bowl.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: lemon pepper
description: Lemon-pepper is a mixture of granulated lemon zest/peel, black peppercorns, and sometimes with other ingredients, such as garlic, onion, sugar, citric acid, salt, and maltodextrin (derived from cornstarch). It is commonly used on chicken and seafood as a seasoning.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: lemongrass
description:
Cymbopogon citriodora West-Indian lemon grass
Cymbopogon flexuosus East-Indian lemon grass
Cymbopogon winterianus Jowitt Citronella grass
Cymbopogon martini
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: lentil
description: The Lentil is a small legume shaped like a lens. It is commonly used in soup, often in combination with barley or rice.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: lettuce
description: Lettuce is a temperate plant grown for its leaves, which are used in salads, sandwiches, and several other dishes. Lettuce is generally used raw and in cold dishes, but in South-East Asian cooking it is used as a 'wrap' around a hot filling.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: lima bean
description: The lima bean, also known as the chad bean or butter bean, is a large disk-shaped bean used in succotash. Lima beans originated in Peru and have been grown there since 6000 B.C. The name comes from the capital city of Peru, Lima. Lima beans are almost always called "butter beans" in the southern part of the United States, even in markets and restaurants.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: lime
description: Limes are sour green citrus fruit. Limes may be substituted for lemons, and lime juice for lemon juice. The outermost surface contains flavorful oils that may be scraped off with a zester, serrated knife, or grater. As with other citrus fruit, slices are often used to decorate drinks.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: liquid smoke
description: Liquid smoke is a substance produced from smoke passed through water. Liquid smoke is used for both food preservation and flavouring. Liquid smoke consists of smoke produced through the controlled burning of wood chips or sawdust, condensed and then passed through water, which captures and dissolves the smoke-flavoured components in solution. This base can be condensed and modified through many methods to develop a wide range of smoke flavours.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: liquorice
description: Liquorice or Licorice is a sweetener and spice. It smells somewhat like star anise, fennel and anise.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: liver
description: The largest and one of the most important organs, liver has immense nutritional value, providing, that is, that it comes from a fairly young animal. Because liver acts as a clearing house for substances that enter the body, it tends to store and absorb unwanted chemicals, medicines and hormones that an animal might be fed. Naturally, the older the animal the greater the accumulation of these unwanted substances, which, according to some, offset liver's nutritional value. For this very reason, many people choose the more expensive calf's liver over beef liver. There are several ways to distinguish between the two. The color of beef liver is reddish-brown, compared to the paler pinkish-brown of calf's liver. Liver from a mature animal also has a stronger odor and flavor than that from a youngster. Additionally, it will be less tender.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: lobster
description: Lobsters are crustaceans related to shrimp, crab, crayfish, and krill.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: longan
description: The longan is a fruit.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: lox
description: Lox is thin slices of salmon, sometimes smoked, that are traditionally put on bagels with cream cheese for breakfast.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: lychee
description: The lychee is a fruit. The fruit is usually eaten fresh. Don't eat the pit.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: macadamia
description: The macadamia is a nut native to Australia, and cultivated in various countries. Despite being a native of Australia, the largest producer of macadamia nuts is Hawaii.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: macaroni
description: Macaroni is a pasta that is in the shape of a hollow tube. Macaroni is often used to make Macaroni and Cheese, as well as some soups and casseroles.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: mackerel
description: Mackerel is an oily-fleshed sea fish found throughout the oceans of the world. The flesh is strong-flavoured and the fish is bony, which means it is not a fish for beginners.
attribution: Content from Wikibooks Cookbook (https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Cookbook:Table_of_Contents) Available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)

name: madeira wine
description: Madeira is a fortified wine made in the Madeira Islands, Portugal, which is made in a variety of styles ranging from dry wines which can be consumed on their own as an aperitif, to sweet wines more usually consumed with dessert. Cheaper versions are often used in cooking. Due to the unique maturation process the wines undergo, they are especially long-lived.
